awd_abstract_narration:
This project creates and I-Corps Site at Wichita State University (WSU).

NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors. 

The WSU I-Corps Site project goals are to:
(1)Synchronize a synergistic research and innovation ecosystem to more rapidly translate Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) research and technologies into new and existing business and industry,
(2)Strengthen and further develop WSU research and industry collaborations, 
(3)Enhance the educational environment increasing understanding of innovation and entrepreneurship, and 
(4)Leverage STEM discoveries and innovations to increase U.S. competitiveness and create jobs.

The WSU I-Corps Site program supports entrepreneurial students, faculty, and researchers and strategically equips them to accelerate their ideas, research, processes and products into market-driven commercial applications, profitable enterprises, and start-up companies, and/or toward becoming I-Corps Team applicants. The support includes infrastructure, guidance, resources, networking opportunities, training, and funding to enable WSU innovators and I-Corps Site Teams to mature and commercialize their ideas and spur the development of 21st century jobs and industries. Project outcomes include development of investor-ready business models, direct commercialization of technology, business start-ups, licensing agreements, and increased applications submitted by WSU Site Teams to the NSF's I-Corps Team Program.

The I-Corps Site activities expand on the university's existing strengths, creating momentum to spur increased engagement with student and faculty, increasing the pipeline of innovations from the university, increasing interaction and engagement with local entrepreneurial mentors, and promoting entrepreneurial and commercial thinking.

The Broader Impacts for this Site include expanded development of a more diversified innovation ecosystem model that can be applied in other geographic regions. The additional knowledge gained from targeted entrepreneurship curriculum enables the WSU innovation ecosystem to attract and promote student and faculty innovations and research to improve the advanced manufacturing cluster, with particular focus on unrepresented groups (minorities, female, lower income populations). Entrepreneurial training/educational modules embed the entrepreneurial concepts into STEM and other innovation activities. Societal and economic impacts include enhancing and strengthening the Midwest innovation ecosystem, and contributing to stronger technology-based economic development in Kansas, job creation and retention, wealth creation, healthier work environment, student education, venture capital investment, and business start-ups and expansions.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Wichita State Universitys I-Corps Site program, Shocker I-Corps, began in 2016 and has nurtured and supported 123 entrepreneurial teams interested in transitioning their STEM ideas, devices, and processes into the marketplace in anticipation of profit.  Direct support to I-Corps Site teams included funded activities such as, but not limited to: (1) increased university discovery and development of STEM processes, products, and ideas with commercial potential, (2) prototype development, (3) focused mentoring through an expanded network of partners and alumni, business and industry experts, and experienced start-up mentors, (4) increased student and personnel understanding of entrepreneurship and commercialization promoted through entrepreneurship curriculum and workshops, (5) travel to visit potential customers or industry experts, and (6) enhanced and deliberate identification, recruitment, and vetting of diverse entrepreneurial teams to broaden the pipeline of student and faculty team projects that can be commercialized. These efforts provided infrastructure, guidance, resources, networking opportunities, training, and funding to enable WSU and other regional university innovators to mature and work toward commercializing their ideas or determine they were not viable for current commercialization.

The Intellectual Merits of I-Corps Site activities resulted in expanding on the university?s existing strengths, creating momentum to spur increased engagement with student and faculty, increased the pipeline of innovations from the university, increased interaction, and engagement with local entrepreneurial mentors, and promoted entrepreneurial and commercial thinking.  The initiatives activities enabled an accelerated transition of student and faculty innovations to industry applications and commercialization and inspired the development of additional technical and entrepreneurial curricula and training programs which were developed to equip STEM professionals with the skills, talent, and knowledge that are essential to expand the capabilities and innovative outcomes of the workforce.

The Broader Impacts of the initiative include expanded development of a more diversified innovation ecosystem model within the university.  The additional knowledge gained from targeted entrepreneurship curriculum enables the WSU innovation ecosystem to more effectively attract and promote student and faculty innovations and research to improve the advanced manufacturing cluster, with particular focus on unrepresented groups (minorities, female, lower income populations) in the region.   

The Shocker I-Corps teams participated in interactive and engaging 8-week training, facilitated by university and community entrepreneurs with access to a mentor network for group and individualized guidance.

Through this interactive process, participants have learned to clearly conceptualize how their product or service can provide real value to customers. Participants were taught how to validate their value proposition with customers and other stakeholders. In addition, the program assisted in the development of a business model that delivers a value proposition to customers and provides a framework and methodology to create a viable startup company.

Since the inception of the Shocker I-Corps program in the Summer of 2016, a total of 123 teams participated in the program, through the Fall of 2021.  The following outcomes were achieved by the participating teams.

  • The program has assisted 14 teams in launching new companies
  • Teams that determined to move forward with their idea after completing the program have collectively secured over $5 Million in additional funding
  • Participating teams went on to win 16 entrepreneurship competitions
  • Two teams have been accepted to the I-Corps National program through NSF with a $50,000 grant 
  • Two teams participated in the Venturewell E-Team program with a $5,000 grant
  • Two teams secured licensing agreements with companies to commercialize their technology
  • 14 Patents have been issued for participating technologies

 


Last Modified: 02/23/2022
Modified by: John S Tomblin
